text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with tomato and dirt salad that's
right I know it sounds delicious but
would a tomato and dirt salad actually
taste as good as it sounds well thanks
to some extremely crispy rye crumbs the
answer was yes pluses you'll read about
in the post actually stole this recipe
from a bowling alley so you know it's
got to be good so to get started we're
going to prep some mushrooms this is
going to be the first of three main
ingredients in our dirt mixture so I'm
gonna take three Brown mushrooms and
slice them up and once I slice them I'm
going to start chopping them and I'm
going to keep chopping them until
they're very very fine and of course
we're using mushrooms here for their
earthy goodness one could argue that
mushrooms are basically living dirt so
that's going to be a very important
flavor component here so like I said
keep chopping and chopping until you
have a very very very fine dice and
we're going to transfer those into a
skillet with a little bit of olive oil
well actually more than a little bit a
few tablespoons over medium-high heat
along with a big pinch of salt and we're
going to cook those mushrooms until they
completely dry out and turn golden brown
we definitely want all that moisture to
evaporate we want to concentrate those
flavors we want to get these as meaty
and earthy tasting as possible we
definitely want some nice color which is
another reason we cut these so tiny we
don't want big light color chunks in our
dirt because some smartass foodie friend
will be like hey I thought this was dirt
not potting soil so like I said that's
going to take a few minutes and we'll
keep an eye on it but while that's
cooking we can move on to dirt
ingredient number two which is rye bread
so I have three slices of dark rye
that's as dark as I could find it if you
could actually find darker I that would
work even better and we're going to
break that bread up into the food
processor and we're going to pulse it on
and off until we have some fairly fine
crumbs and it definitely works better if
the breads a day or two old
having said that mine was totally fresh
right out of the package and it worked
fine so we're going to process that off
and on until we have crumbs and then
just reserve that until our mushrooms
are ready we should be very soon so once
that water evaporates those mushrooms
are going to brown pretty quickly
all right in fact I usually turn my heat
down a little at this point okay so that
probably took me seven or eight minutes
total and when the mushrooms look like
that we're going to go ahead and dump in
our rye crumbs I'm going to adjust the
heat to about medium and we're going to
basically toast those bread crumbs until
they get crisp and at first
a good amount of steam escaping that
bread was fairly moist but eventually
will dry out and start to crisp up now
at this point you have to decide whether
you have enough olive oil to make that
happen all right once you mix it all in
if it seems a little dry which mine did
go ahead and drizzle in a little more
oil and then give that a mix and keep
cooking it and by the way if you learned
how to flip stuff in a pan with our now
famous cheese balls video you can
definitely use that technique here
perfect application for it we're going
to keep those crumbs moving we're going
to keep them moving until they start to
crisp up and how you know that's
happening you can kind of feel it with
the spatula but you're also going to go
by sound when the end is nearing you'll
be hearing something that sounds like
this at that point we're going to add
the last of our dirty ingredients which
is going to be some ground almonds also
known as almond flour I had some left
over from our macaron video and no you
don't have to buy almond flour just chop
or crush some almonds and make your own
so we're going to stir that in and not
only is that going to add another
dimension of flavor but it's also going
to make our dirt look even more
realistic almost like fine specks of
sand or stone in the dirt all right but
we don't want those specks bright white
so I want you to keep cooking this on
medium tossing it constantly for at
least 3 or 4 more minutes until those
little pieces of almond toast up and
everything gets perfectly crispy if you
want to play it safe you can lower the
heat a little bit maybe down to
medium-low and just keep toasting until
you're sure it's done so I gave my tea
taste here be careful it's hot but it
was absolutely crispy and I don't know
if delicious is the right word but it
was exactly what I was after
it was grainy crispy earthy with a
slightly bitter edge so at this point
our dirt is done we're gonna let that

we're going to go ahead and build our
